markdownRemark.html:
Score: 92.5

eagletribune.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of The Eagle-Tribune, a daily newspaper serving portions of northeastern Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire.  

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The Eagle-Tribune is owned by CNHI, also known as Community Newspaper Holdings Inc., a Montgomery, Alabama-based company that owns more than 60 daily newspapers and more than 40 nondaily publications across the United States. CNHI is a subsidiary of Raycom Media, a privately held Montgomery, Alabama-based broadcast company. Raycom announced in June 2018 that it would be purchased by Gray Television, a publicly traded, Atlanta-based media company, for $3.6 billion. CNHI wouldl not be acquired by Gray as a part of this deal.

The site derives revenue from advertising and subscription fees.

Content

Eagletribune.com covers government, politics, business, entertainment, and sports in the Merrimack Valley in northeastern Massachusetts and parts of southern New Hampshire. Most of the site’s local coverage is produced by staff reporters. State, national, and international content is provided by The Associated Press.

Credibility

Articles generally use measured language and reference multiple, first-hand sources. Headlines accurately reflect content.

Eagletribune.com regularly posts corrections to its articles, generally by appending a short editor’s note at the top of the article and a full-length correction at the end, explaining the error and how it was corrected.  

Opinion is published in a separate section.

The paper’s reporting on the Massachusetts prison furlough program, which won the Pulitzer Prize in General News Reporting in 1988, helped lead to abolishment of the state’s use of furloughs for people convicted of first-degree murder.

In 2003, it won another Pulitzer Prize, in the category of Breaking News Reporting, for its coverage of the accidental drowning of four boys in the Merrimack River.

Transparency

Articles typically include the name of the writer, along with contact information. The site provides biographical and contact information for its management and news staff.

Advertising is distinguished from news content.

The site indicates in its About Us and Contact Us sections that it is part of the North of Boston Media Group, but does not disclose that it is owned by CNHI or Raycom. The Eagle Tribune's senior digital editor, Alexandra Nicholas, said in a phone interview with NewsGuard that the template for the Eagle-Tribune’s website is provided by CNHI. She also said that the outlet refers to its ownership in articles about the newspaper.

History

The Eagle-Tribune launched as The Essex Eagle in 1867.

Written by:
Lillian Childress

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Eric Effron
